availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p: A year or two ago several judgments were rendered in the Breckinridge Circuit Court against James Cox & Saml S Wall for $60- each & costs on a joint indictment agst. them for keeping a Tipling House --

The facts are that Cox kept in good faith in a Town of Union Star a Tavern & had license to sell spirits therein -- His license had expired a few days when Wall who livid with him sold some spirits ^in the presense of Cox^ -- The license was renewed as soon as Cox discovered that it had expired -- I think The jury & maybe the Court united in a petition for their release which has been mislaid -- This case has strong claims on the Executive clemency --
